title: Enneapogon nigricans
text:
Enneapogon nigricans, known by the common names blackheads, bottle washers, pappus grass, purpletop grass, and niggerheads, is a perennial Australian <a href="grass">grass</a>.
Distinctive lance-shaped seedheads appear in late <a href="spring%20%28season%29">spring</a> and <a href="summer">summer</a>. They form at the top of wiry stalks over 30 cm long. They start as an olive green colour, but dry to a light brown. The seed itself is much like a <a href="parasol">parasol</a> in appearance, and is around 5mm across. <a href="Germination">Germination</a> is slow and unreliable and requires warm temperatures.
Leaves are smooth and of a bright, light green. Plants like sunny positions and generally grow in sunny, open <a href="Mallee%20Woodlands%20and%20Shrublands">mallee</a> forests. Plants form tall dense tussocks to a maximum of only 20 cm across. They die down in late summer, before reshooting when the rains return.
